content:
Use the uploaded photograph as the only visual reference.
The personâ€™s identity must be preserved with maximum accuracy: face, facial features, age, gender, body proportions, and overall appearance must remain unchanged.
Do not invent or add anything that does not exist in the original image.

Step 1: Detailed visual analysis of the source image
First, perform a careful visual analysis of the uploaded image, including:
Who is in the image (person, number of people, position in frame)
Body pose and direction of gaze
Facial expression and emotional mood
Clothing and accessories
Lighting conditions, time of day, color temperature
Environment, background, and depth of space
Overall emotional tone of the scene

Step 2: Cinematic 3Ã—2 storyboard grid
After the analysis, create a cinematic 3Ã—2 grid (6 frames) from the single image, as if it were a sequence of shots from a film.

Global requirements for the entire grid:
Format: one image containing a 3Ã—2 grid
All frames must be numbered 1â€“6, left to right, top to bottom
Visual style: realistic, cinematic, non-illustrative
One consistent character and environment with logical continuity
Each frame must differ by pose, camera angle, or camera distance
The sequence should feel like time is passing and the scene is developing
No facial distortion, no change in identity or appearance

Frame descriptions:

Frame 1 (No. 1)
Wide establishing shot.
The camera is farthest from the subject, showing the full environment and context.
The person feels like part of the surrounding space.

Frame 2 (No. 2)
Medium shot.
The camera moves closer.
The pose changes slightly, revealing inner emotion or state of mind.

Frame 3 (No. 3)
Low-angle or side-angle shot.
Adds drama or tension, emphasizing body shape and perspective.

Frame 4 (No. 4)
Close-up or medium close-up.
Focus on the face, eyes, and emotion.
Fine details are clearly visible.

Frame 5 (No. 5)
Dynamic angle: diagonal composition or camera movement.
The pose changes the most, creating a sense of action or momentum.

Frame 6 (No. 6)
Final shot.
Calm, reflective, or emotionally resolved.
The camera may be closer or farther, but the frame feels like a conclusion.

Lighting & cinematic consistency:
Lighting must remain logically consistent across all frames, as if filmed in one continuous scene.

Depth of field, lighting, and color grading should reinforce a cinematic look.

Final result:
The output should resemble a professional cinematic storyboard, captured in a single take and location, with strong realism and narrative flow.
title: Cinematic 3x2 storyboard grid from a single image reference
description: A complex, multi-step prompt designed to generate a cinematic 3x2 storyboard grid (6 frames) from a single uploaded photograph (Jennifer Lawrence). It requires preserving the subject's identity and environment while varying the camera angles (Wide, Medium, Low-angle, Close-up, Dynamic, Final Shot) to create a narrative flow, emphasizing realism and cinematic consistency.

content: Photorealistic cinematic film still, live-action (no CGI). Preserve the subjectâ€™s identity exactly from the reference photo: same facial structure, asymmetry, skin texture, pores, dirt, sweat. No beautification. Three-quarter body portrait, vertical: Torso angled sideways, head toward camera. Hands gripping a rugged improvised shotgun at waist level. Wasteland survivor â€“ Mad Max: Fury Road inspired. Practical, battle-worn realism. Environment: open desert wasteland, orange sand and dust clouds, saturated turquoise sky. Background: slightly blurred post-apocalyptic pursuit vehicle, sense of imminent chaos. Subtle motion blur and heat haze. Lighting: harsh overhead desert sun, extremely hard shadows. Rich detail in sun-blached physique, sense of dust-caked skin and deep shadow. Sweat and grease catching sharp specks of light. Wardrobe & details: distressed leather, scarf around neck, dusty worn gear. Windblown messy hair. Face smeared with engine grease and sand (naturalistic). Look & color: shot on 35mm film, Kodak Vision3 feel. Contrast. Strong teal & orange grading, realistic skin tones. Emphasis on tactile realism: rusted metal, sand particles, sweat, grease, fabric weave. Final: raw, realistic; sun-blasted, high-energy cinematic still.

Use the uploaded image of the character as an exact reference. Preserve the original proportions, materials, colors, textures, and facial features. Do not alter the design and do not stylize the character.

A first-person point-of-view shot inside an abandoned space [LOCATION TYPE: television studio/advertising set/real filming location].

The viewer is holding a flashlight, creating a single circular beam of light while the rest of the space is engulfed in darkness. In the flashlight beam, it is visible that the character is positioned as if it was left behind after filming: [POSITION: lying on the floor/curled up in a corner/leaning against a table/slumped against a wall]. The character must appear completely lifeless and inactive: no action, no intentional pose, no sense of presence. If it is a doll or a costume, there must be no visible hands, rods, strings, or person inside.

The character appears old, dirty, and abandoned: worn fabric, accumulated dust, stains, discoloration, flattened or damaged areas.

The environment is clearly abandoned: dusty surfaces, old filming equipment, cables scattered on the floor, faded signs or set decorations.

Dust particles float within the flashlight beam; the space feels silent and untouched for years.

Photorealistic flashlight-based lighting, harsh shadows, rough textures, documentary realism, on-location shooting aesthetics, no stylization Aspect

Ratio 9:16

content:
Output image is 2x2 four-panel split
Video Style: {argument name="video style" default="2000s Japanese Anime OVA style"}
Background:
Late-night city streets. Gaps between deserted roads and skyscrapers. Black liquid splattered from a giant monster adheres to the asphalt and walls. Dust and sparks are flying.

Character 1:
High school girl with long black hair. Wearing a sailor uniform. A Japanese sword is sheathed and hanging at her waist. She looks around cautiously, adopting a low stance.
Character 2:
High school girl with blonde bob hair. Wearing a blazer uniform. Standing behind her companion, holding one hand ready to use her ability at any moment. Her expression is tense.
Enemy Presence:
Black liquid gathers and transforms into a humanoid entity with a fibrous, thread-like texture. Its face is vague, its limbs are unnaturally long, and it crawls across the ground and walls with unnatural movements.

Cut 1:
Close-up of the ground. Filled with black liquid. Flying dust and sparks
Cut 2:
Medium shot. The humanoid anomaly, rising from the black liquid, awkwardly begins to stand up. Thread-like shadows droop, dragging on the ground.
Cut 3:
Low-angle wide shot. Multiple anomalies appear one after another from the roads and walls, encircling the girls in a circle. The cityscape emphasizes the feeling of being surrounded.
Cut 4:
Shot over the girls' backs. In front of them is a horde of black humanoids closing in. The black-haired girl rests her hand on the sheath, and the blonde-haired girl prepares to activate her ability.
The composition emphasizes the tension right before the battle.

content:
STRICT ADHERENCE REQUIRED:
  - Follow this YAML specification precisely. Do NOT deviate, add unauthorized elements, or make 'creative' interpretations.
  - Character identity consistency from reference images (if provided) is PARAMOUNT.
  - Thorough image analysis is mandatory to maintain this consistency. Any result that fails character identity checks is unacceptable.

Strict_Adherence: true
aspect_ratio: "{argument name="aspect ratio" default="2:3"}" # Change as needed (e.g., "1:1", "16:9")
resolution: "{argument name="resolution" default="2K"}"    # Change as needed (e.g., "4K")
Character_Count: {{ Total number of characters appearing }}
Total_Panel_Count: {{ Total number of panels (usually 4-8 for a 4-tier structure) }}

Summary: >
  {argument name="summary" default="Overall summary of the story. Briefly describe the plot flow, setting, main events, and conclusion."}

Style_Guide:
  # Panel division style is fixed to "no outer frame, display to canvas edge"
  comic_style: "4-tier, multi-panel manga strip with no outer framing border. The panels should extend to the very edge of the canvas, separated only by the inner white dividing lines."
  lighting: "{{ Specify lighting. Time of day (day/night), light source (sunlight/electric light/moonlight), atmosphere (bright/dark/dramatic shadows), etc. }}"
  background_elements: "{{ Main setting, specific description of the location, important props or environmental elements placed. }}"
  dialogue_bubbles: "Standard white bubbles for speech, thought clouds for internal thoughts, dashed bubbles for whispers, and rectangular boxes for narration/monologue. {{ Add definitions for special speech bubbles if necessary (e.g., spiky bubbles for shouting) }}"
  visual_effects: "{{ Specify manga visual effects. Manga symbols (sweat, veins, sparkle), effect lines (concentration lines, speed lines, tremor lines), visualization of sound effects, etc. }}"

Characters:
  # Character definition. Alphanumeric IDs recommended.
  {{ Character ID_1 }}:
    description: "{{ Appearance, hairstyle, color, clothing, distinctive items, personality and expression tendencies. If reference images exist, write the file name here (e.g., reference image_0.png). }}"
  {{ Character ID_2 }}:
    description: "{{ Second character details... Describe for the number of characters. }}"
  # Add as needed...

Storyboard:
  # 4-tier panel division definition
  Tier_1:
    {{ Panel ID_T1_P1 (e.g., Panel_1_Large_Top) }}:
      scene: "{{ Specific situation description for this panel. Who, where, and what they are doing. Composition and camera work can also be specified. }}"
      dialogue:
        - speaker: "{{ Speaker's Character ID }}"
          type: "{{ Type of line: speech(normal), thought(thought), whisper(whisper), shout(shout), monologue(monologue/narration) }}"
          text: "{{ Specific content of the line. Use \n if a line break is needed. }}"
        # Add list if there are multiple lines in the same panel
        # - speaker: "..."
        #   type: "..."
        #   text: "..."
    # Write here to add panels to Tier_1
  Tier_2:
    {{ Panel ID_T2_P1 }}:
      scene: "{{ Scene details }}"
      dialogue:
        - speaker: "{{ Speaker ID }}"
          type: "{{ Type }}"
          text: "{{ Content }}"
    # Add panels as needed
  Tier_3:
    {{ Panel ID_T3_P1 }}:
      scene: "{{ Scene details }}"
      dialogue:
        - speaker: "{{ Speaker ID }}"
          type: "{{ Type }}"
          text: "{{ Content }}"
    # Add panels as needed
  Tier_4:
    {{ Panel ID_T4_P1 }}:
      scene: "{{ Scene details }}"
      dialogue:
        - speaker: "{{ Speaker ID }}"
          type: "{{ Type }}"
          text: "{{ Content }}"
    # Add panels as needed

A hyper-realistic, surreal composite shot utilizing forced perspective to create a dramatic scale difference, featuring an extreme close-up profile view on the right side of a man with uploaded face as reference, his expression one of slack-jawed astonishment with mouth slightly agape as he gazes downward. His large hand extends into the focal plane on the left, palm upturned and open, cradling a tiny, miniature version of a man standing directly on the skin of the palm; the miniature figure is dressed in a black t-shirt and loose beige khaki trousers, captured in a dynamic, slightly crouched stance as if balancing or reacting to the giant. The cinematography employs a shallow depth of field with an 85mm portrait lens, keeping the giant's profile and the miniature figure in sharp focus while rendering the backgroundâ€”a warm-toned domestic interior with reddish-brown wooden cabinetry and vague blue shapesâ€”into a creamy, soft bokeh. The lighting is warm and naturalistic, suggestive of indoor tungsten sources, highlighting the skin texture, facial hair, and subsurface scattering on the giant's face, rendered in 8k resolution with the fidelity of an Octane Render, emphasizing the absurdity and realism of the "shrunk" subject matter.

Man should be fully visible

content:
You are a "professional manga writer" and "AI Art Director". Based on the [Character Image] and [Theme] I provide, please create a **10-page manga generation prompt sequence that can be used directly with NanoBananaPro (high-performance image generation AI)**.

## Production Requirements (NanoBananaPro Hybrid Optimized)
1. **Output Format**:
Â  Â - Output each page in a `Code Block` format that is easy to copy and paste.
Â  Â - **Language Specification (Hybrid Strategy)**:
Â  Â  Â - **Visual Description (Visuals)**: Character, background, and art style specifications should be in **"English"** to maintain consistency.
Â  Â  Â - **Text Rendering**: Dialogue and sound effects within speech bubbles should be specified in **"Japanese"**.
Â  Â  Â - **Aspect Ratio**: Each page should be structured assuming a `Vertical 9:16 aspect ratio`.

2. **Utilization of NanoBananaPro Specific Features**:
Â  Â - **Text Rendering**:
Â  Â  Â - This model can accurately render Japanese text within the image.
Â  Â  Â - Describe the Japanese dialogue by writing `Text: "[Japanese Dialogue]"` in the Prompt.
Â  Â  Â - **Contextual Understanding**:
Â  Â  Â - Describe the situation using English close to natural language, not just a list of words.

3. **Story Structure and Direction**:
Â  Â - **Title Determination**: Devise a "high-sense title" that reflects the theme, conveys the content at a glance, and captures interest.
Â  Â  Â - **Title Logo Placement**:
Â  Â  Â - Create a "Title Panel" where the title logo is prominently placed on **Page 1 or Page 2**.
Â  Â  Â - **Rendering Instruction**: Include instructions to render the title text itself as "decorative typography" within the image.
Â  Â  Â - **"Setup and Punchline" Structure**:
Â  Â  Â - **Page 1 (The Hook)**: Include a "strong setup (mystery, shock, empathy)" that strongly captures the reader's interest.
Â  Â  Â - **Page 10 (The Punchline)**: The conclusion, or a cliffhanger leading to the next part.

4. **Page Description Rules (Strictly Enforced)**:
Â  Â The prompt must always include the following sections.
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **Header**: `ã€IMAGE_GEN_ONLYã€‘: Generate a high-resolution professional Japanese manga page. Full Color. Vertical 9:16. 4K.`
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **ã€STRICT CHARACTER CONSISTENCY (English)ã€‘**:
Â  Â  Â - **Important**: The **"Character Appearance Description (English)"** created by analyzing the initial image must be written in the prompt for **all pages**, without changing a single word.
Â  Â  Â - **Prohibition**: "Omission" or "As above" is **strictly forbidden**. The entire definition must be written out every time.
Â  Â  Â - Example: `Black bob cut hair, red ribbon, golden eyes, wearing a futuristic cyberpunk school uniform.`
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **ã€STRICT STYLE CONSISTENCY (English)ã€‘**:
Â  Â  Â - **Style Analysis and Fixation**: Analyze the input image and define its characteristics (Lines, Color, Lighting) as a detailed English prompt.
Â  Â  Â - **Prohibition**: This is also **forbidden** to "omit". Output the full text every time.
Â  Â  Â - Example: `Thick confident outlines, cel shading with soft gradients, vibrant high-saturation colors, dramatic lighting, anime screentones.`

Â  Â - **ã€PANEL LAYOUT & VISUALS (English + Japanese Text)ã€‘**:
Â  Â  Â - **Panel Composition**: **Always place 4 to 8 panels** per page. (3 panels or less is forbidden)
Â  Â  Â - **Content Description**:
Â  Â  Â  Â - `Panel 1 (Top-Right):`
Â  Â  Â  Â - `Visual: [English description of action/angle]`
Â  Â  Â  Â - `Text: "[Japanese Dialogue in bubble]"`

Â  Â - **ã€PAGE NUMBERINGã€‘**:
Â  Â  Â - Instruction to render the page number (e.g., "1") small in the bottom-right corner.

## Output Template Example

### Page X

```text
ã€IMAGE_GEN_ONLYã€‘: Generate a high-resolution professional Japanese manga page. Full Color. Vertical 9:16. --ar 9:16

# STRICT CHARACTER CONSISTENCY (DO NOT CHANGE)
[Paste the EXACT English Master Description here... NO ABBREVIATIONS]

# STRICT STYLE CONSISTENCY (DO NOT CHANGE)
[Paste the EXACT English Master Style Description here... NO ABBREVIATIONS]

# PAGE NUMBER
Small clear text "X" in the bottom-right corner.

# PANEL LAYOUT & VISUALS (Target: 5-8 Panels, Top-Right to Bottom-Left)

## Panel 1 (Top-Right):
- Visual: [English description of the scene and action]
- Text: "[Japanese Dialogue]"

content:
You are a "Professional Manga Writer" and "AI Art Director."
Based on the [Character Image] and [Theme] I provide, please create **10 pages of manga generation prompts that can be used directly with NanoBananaPro (high-performance image generation AI)**.

## Production Requirements (NanoBananaPro Optimized)
1. **Output Format**:
Â  Â - Output each page in a `Code Block` format that is easy to copy and paste.
Â  Â - **Language Specification**: All prompt descriptions must be in **"Japanese (Japanese)"**. Utilize NanoBananaPro's Japanese understanding to provide natural and detailed instructions, not translation-like phrasing.
Â  Â - **Aspect Ratio**: Each page must be composed assuming a `Vertical 9:16 aspect ratio`.

2. **Utilization of NanoBananaPro Specific Features**:
Â  Â - **Text Rendering**:
Â  Â  Â - This model can accurately draw text within the image.
Â  Â  Â - Instructions for each panel must clearly include **instructions to render "dialogue within speech bubbles" and "hand-drawn text (onomatopoeia) in the background" as part of the image**.
Â  Â - **Contextual Understanding**:
Â  Â  Â - Prioritize descriptions in **sentence form (natural language)**â€”"who is doing what, where, and with what emotion"â€”rather than a list of tokens.

3. **Story Composition and Direction**:
Â  Â - **Title Determination**: Devise a "high-sense title" that reflects the theme, conveys the content at a glance, and captures interest.
Â  Â - **Title Logo Placement**:
Â  Â  Â - Create a "title panel" on **Page 1 or Page 2** where the title logo is prominently placed.
Â  Â  Â - **Drawing Instruction**: Include instructions to render the title text itself as "decorative typography" within the image.
Â  Â - **"Setup and Payoff" Structure**:
Â  Â  Â - **Page 1 (The Hook)**: Include a "strong hook (mystery, shock, empathy)" that strongly captures the reader's interest.
Â  Â  Â - **Page 10 (The Punchline)**: The punchline or a cliffhanger leading to the next part.

4. **Rules for Describing Each Page (Strictly Enforced)**:
Â  Â The prompt must always include the following sections.
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **Header**: `High-resolution professional Japanese manga page. Full color. Vertical (9:16).`
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **[Character Definition (Fixed)]**:
Â  Â  Â - **Important**: Create a Japanese definition sentence of the **"Character's Appearance Description (clothes, hairstyle, color, accessories)"** analyzed from the initial image, and write it in the **prompt for every page** without changing a single word.
Â  Â  Â - Example Description: "A girl with black bob-cut hair, a red ribbon, golden eyes, wearing a futuristic cyberpunk uniform."
Â  Â 
Â  Â - **[Art Style Definition (Fixed)]**:
Â  Â  Â - **Art Style Analysis and Fixation**: Analyze the input image and define its art style (line thickness, coloring touch, lighting) as a detailed Japanese prompt.
Â  Â  Â - This must also be written in the **prompt for every page**.
Â  Â  Â - Example Description: "Clear, confident main lines, anime coloring with soft gradients, high saturation and vivid colors, dramatic lighting."

Â  Â - **[Panel Layout & Visuals]**:
Â  Â  Â - **Panel Composition**: **Must place 4 to 8 panels** per page. (Fewer than 3 panels is forbidden)
Â  Â  Â - **Eye Guidance**: Specify the placement of each panel (e.g., "top right panel," "bottom left panel") following the Japanese manga format (top right â†’ top left â†’ bottom right â†’ bottom left).
Â  Â  Â - **Content must include the following elements**:
Â  Â  Â  Â 1. **Situation Description**: Character acting, angle, background.
Â  Â  Â  Â 2. **Text Rendering Specification**: Dialogue to be placed in speech bubbles, or sound effects.

Â  Â - **[Page Number]**:
Â  Â  Â - Instruction to draw a small page number (e.g., "1") in the bottom right corner.

## Output Template Example

### Page X

```text
High-resolution professional Japanese manga page. Full color. Vertical (9:16).

# [Character Definition (Fixed - Do Not Change)]
[Paste the detailed Japanese description of the analyzed character here...]

# [Art Style Definition (Fixed - Do Not Change)]
[Paste the detailed Japanese description of the analyzed art style here...]

# [Page Number]
Draw the number "X" in a small, clear font in the bottom right corner of the image.

# [Panel Layout & Content (5-8 panels, from top right to bottom left)]

## Panel 1 (Top Right):
- **Situation**: [Composition such as close-up or long shot, and character acting]
- **Text Rendering**: Draw "[Dialogue]" inside a speech bubble.

## Panel 2 (Top Left):
- **Situation**: ...
- **Text Rendering**: Large hand-drawn text "[Onomatopoeia]" in the background. "[Dialogue]" in a speech bubble.

## Panel 3 (Middle Right):
- **Situation**: ...
- **Text Rendering**: ...

(Continue for the number of panels)

## Panel 6 (Bottom Left):
- **Situation**: ...
- **Text Rendering**: ...

Upon receiving an image (or instructions for an image) from the user, first reply with **"I have confirmed the character image."**
Next, determine if the image is [Live-Action] or [Illustration] and present a **"Draft Art Style Definition Prompt"** based on that determination.

content:
**CORE INSTRUCTION FOR THE MODEL:**
Analyze the personality traits and potential conflicts of the CHARACTERS previously provided as input. You must infer how these specific individuals would interact and place them into the four scenarios below based on their likelihood to be involved in that specific type of scene (e.g., put gossips in the confessional, aggressors in the fight scene).

**MANDATORY VISUAL AESTHETIC ("Real Broadcast Look"):**
The images must NOT look like staged photography. They must look like raw, unpolished TV broadcast footage.
* **Crucial Details:** Every panel must include on-screen graphics: timestamps (e.g., "DAY 12 | 14:32"), camera location identifiers (e.g., "CAM 1 - LIVING AREA"), and a small, semi-transparent channel logo in a corner.
* **Textures:** Expect video grain, slight lens distortion, harsh fluorescent lighting, and occasional digital compression artifacts.

**GRID BREAKDOWN (2x2 Layout):**

**[TOP ROW]**
* **[PANEL 1: Top-Left] Domestic Friction (Kitchen/Living Area).** Wide-angle fixed CCTV camera shot. Harsh, unflattering overhead lighting. Based on inputs, show a tense moment of daily lifeâ€”two characters with incompatible habits arguing over cleaning or food, while others sit uncomfortably in the background. The composition is messy and naturalistic.
* **[PANEL 2: Top-Right] The Confessional Booth (El Confesionario).** Tight, claustrophobic fish-eye lens close-up. The background is a simple, soundproofed wall. Select the character most likely to vent or gossip from the inputs. They are looking directly into the lens, highly emotional (crying or angrily gesturing), breaking the fourth wall.

**[BOTTOM ROW]**
* **[PANEL 3: Bottom-Left] Night Vision Secrets (Bedroom).** Monochrome green or grey infrared night-vision shot. Grainy, low fidelity. Total darkness in the room. Show two characters (strategic allies based on inputs) whispering conspiratorially in a bed, barely visible under covers.
* **[PANEL 4: Bottom-Right] The Explosion (Garden/Smoking Area).** Chaotic, slightly shaky "handheld camera" feel, as if an operator ran to catch the action. High drama. A screaming argument at a party or nighttime gathering. The most volatile characters from the inputs are being physically separated by others. Flashing lights or dramatic shadows.

**STYLE:** Raw reality TV broadcast screenshots, 2x2 grid, highly detailed, 4k

Please generate a manga page.

#Character (Highest Priority):
**[Important: Perfect reproduction of the attached image (image_urls)] This is not a reference image but an â€œunalterable master data.â€ Strictly adhere to the following processes in all generated panels.**

1. **Fixing Features:** Maintain 100% of the attached image's **â€œhair style, hair color, eye shape, clothing, and accessories.â€** Unauthorized arrangements or simplifications are prohibited.
2. **Deformation Rules:** When applying the #Style (chibi character), **only the â€œhead-to-body ratioâ€ should be reduced, and the â€œface part arrangement and hairstyle designâ€ must not deviate from the attached image.**
3. **Maintaining Identity:** Even if the angle changes, it must be â€œthe same character viewed from a different angle.â€ Do not change the face to look like a different person.
4. **Do not cause â€œPrompt Bleed (instruction leakage).â€**

#Output Size
9:16
#Style:
**Basic Art Style:** Monochrome, Japanese manga, gag manga style, thick outline lines.
**Style prompt:** Japanese manga, chibi style, thick outline lines, monochrome.
**Format:** Vertical writing, Japanese panel layout read from right to left.

#Text Generation Rules (Strict Adherence):
**[Important: Natural Japanese and Elimination of Duplication]**
When generating dialogue in the manga, perform proofreading immediately before output to absolutely prevent the following errors:

1. **Prohibition of Tautology:** Do not repeat the same word or conjunction twice, such as â€œthat is, that is,â€ â€œbut, but,â€ or â€œreally, really.â€ Stuttering expressions are prohibited.
2. **Natural Colloquial Language:** Use natural speech appropriate for the character's personality, not textbook sentences.
3. **Garbled Text Check:** Confirm that Kanji and Hiragana are not corrupted.

#Direction/Camera Work:
**[Important: Direction while maintaining features]**
Use the following camera work within the range that does not distort the character's face or hairstyle to avoid monotony:

- **Close-up:** Emphasizing emotion (â€»Do not overly deform facial parts)
- **Long Shot:** Explaining the situation
- **High/Low Angle:** Expressing impact or cuteness
- **Diagonal Composition:** Expressing agitation or action

#Scenario Progression:
If no specific panel designation is given, summarize and compose in 3 to 5 panels.
Panel arrangement should not be uniform but irregular or free-form, while maintaining the line of sight guidance from â€œtop right to bottom left.â€

#Negative Prompt (Elements to Avoid):
**repeating words, stuttering text, duplicate phrases, tautology,** altering character design, changing hair color, changing hairstyle, different outfit, monotonous composition, repetitive angles, character facing forward in all panels, flat lighting, messy panel borders, text overlap.

content:
# User Input (Rewrite and submit this)
ã€Character Settingsã€‘
{argument name="character settings" default="Brown hair, twin tails, red eyes, fangs, black cloak, white shirt"}

ã€Main Character's Worryã€‘
*   Content: {argument name="worry" default="I want to eat lots of donuts"}

# Command
You are an image generation engine. Follow the steps below to generate one image based on the user's input.
**Do not output intermediate thoughts or script text. Generate the image immediately.**
# Process (Internal Processing)
1. **Automatic Dialogue Determination**:
*   **Main Character**: Monologues the ã€Worryã€‘ input by the user.
*   **Optimistic Mini-Character**: Responds to the worry with a bright "That's great!" and offers support/encouragement.
*   **Pessimistic Mini-Character**: Anticipates the worst-case scenario for the worry, saying "No good..." and despairs.
*   **My-Pace Mini-Character**: **ã€IMPORTANTã€‘Talks about something completely unrelated to the worry (e.g., tonight's dinner, sleepiness, hobbies).**
*   **Logical Mini-Character**: **ã€IMPORTANTã€‘Performs a coin toss and randomly decides to speak either "For" (presenting a rational solution) or "Against" (pointing out risks).**

2. **Image Generation**:
Combine the determined dialogue and character settings into the prompt and generate the image.
### Image Generation Prompt Requirements
*   **Aspect Ratio**: 2:3
*   **Style**: Japanese comic/anime style, high quality.
*   **Composition**:
Four "mini-characters (chibi-style)" of the same character are aligned along the main character's head line.
ã€IMPORTANTã€‘The four mini-characters are lined up "in a horizontal row."
ã€IMPORTANTã€‘The feet of the mini-characters are hidden (overlapping) by the main character's head or hair.
*   **ã€IMPORTANT: Prohibitionsã€‘**:
*   **Absolutely do not write names or roles (e.g., "Logical," "Optimistic") below or around the characters.**
*   **The only place text is allowed is inside the "speech bubbles."**
*   Bottom 1/3 of the screen: Extreme close-up of the main character's face. Serious expression. Thinking, hand on chin or mouth, gaze downward. A large horizontal thought bubble.
*   Top 2/3 of the screen: Four mini-characters are lined up "in a horizontal row" right behind the main character's head.
*   **Important**: The mini-characters are close enough that their feet are hidden by the main character's head or hair.
*   **Mini-Character Arrangement and Pose**:
From left to right:
1. Logical: Serious face, adjusting glasses, or pointing with a finger.
2. My-Pace: Blank face, yawning, or drinking tea.
3. Pessimistic: Pale face, holding head in despair, vertical line effect.
4. Optimistic: Full smile, hands raised in joy, music note mark.
*   **Speech Bubbles**: Add comic-style speech bubbles to each character.

content:
Use the uploaded image only to accurately reconstruct the subjectâ€™s face. Preserve exact facial identity, proportions, skin texture, pores, beard detail, eye shape, and realism. Do not reuse pose, lighting, or composition from the upload.
Create an ultra-realistic cinematic action moment frozen at the absolute peak of chaos.
A powerful adult male fills the extreme foreground, lunging toward the camera with one arm fully extended, fingers reaching past the lens. His expression is pure survival panic â€” eyes wide, mouth open mid-scream. The face is razor-sharp, perfectly integrated, and emotionally intense.
In his other arm, he clutches a panicking tabby cat. The cat is fully alive and reactive: eyes wide and dilated, ears flattened back, mouth open in a silent hiss or scream, whiskers flared, body tense, claws fully extended, hind legs kicking slightly. Fur strands are hyper-detailed and bristled from fear. The catâ€™s panic mirrors the humanâ€™s, amplifying the chaos.
Behind them, a massive stadium environment erupts. A violent explosion blossoms outward, throwing concrete, metal fragments, and dust into the air. A police vehicle is launched sideways mid-blast, twisted realistically, emergency lights flashing through smoke. Human silhouettes are flung backward, suspended mid-air in slow-motion realism.
Lighting is physical and cinematic: blazing orange firelight rim-lighting the subjects, cold blue emergency strobes slicing through smoke, volumetric haze, flying embers, realistic shadow falloff, extreme dynamic range.
Camera is ultra-wide and close, natural perspective distortion, shallow depth of field, sharp subject separation, no fisheye, no artificial blur.
Photorealistic, hyper-detailed, cinematic color grading.
No cartoon look. No AI artifacts. No softness.
Mood: explosive, intense, absurdly unforgettable, viral blockbuster realism.

content:
Study the uploaded image carefully and fully internalize the scene: the subjectâ€™s appearance, clothing, posture, emotional state, and the surrounding environment. Treat this moment as a single frozen point in time.
Create a cinematic image set that feels like a photographer methodically explored this exact moment from multiple distances and angles, without changing anything about the subject or location.
All images must clearly belong to the same scene, captured under the same lighting conditions, weather, and atmosphere. Nothing in the world changes â€” only the camera position and framing evolve.
The emotional tone should remain consistent throughout the set, subtly expressed through posture, gaze, and micro-expressions rather than exaggerated acting.
Begin by observing the subject within the environment from afar, letting the surroundings dominate the frame and establish scale and mood.
Gradually move closer, allowing the subjectâ€™s full presence to emerge, then narrowing attention toward body language and facial expression.
End with intimate perspectives that reveal small but meaningful details â€” texture, touch, or eye focus â€” before shifting perspective above and below the subject to suggest reflection, vulnerability, or quiet resolve.
Across the sequence:
Wider views should emphasize space and atmosphere
Mid-range views should emphasize posture and emotional context
Close views should isolate feeling and detail
Perspective shifts (low and high angles) should feel purposeful and cinematic, not decorative
Depth of field must behave naturally: distant views remain mostly sharp, while closer frames introduce shallow focus and gentle background separation.
The final result should read as a cohesive 3Ã—3 cinematic contact sheet, as if selected from a single roll of film documenting one emotional moment from multiple viewpoints.
No text, symbols, signage, watermarks, numbers, or graphic elements may appear anywhere in the images.
Photorealistic rendering, cinematic color grading, and consistent visual realism are mandatory.

It instructs the model to internalize the scene and subject, then create a sequence of images captured from multiple distances and angles while maintaining absolute consistency in subject, location, lighting, and emotional tone.

content: "A single cohesive square image divided into a clean 2x2 grid with thin black borders, telling a sequential sci-fi space drama story of a tough female bounty hunter capturing and delivering her bounty at a galactic outpost. Character consistency (exact same in every panel): Bounty Hunter: Mid-30s athletic woman with short cropped silver hair, scarred cheek, wearing rugged black leather jacket with glowing neon accents, tactical pants, heavy boots, blaster holster on thigh, stern determined expression, cybernetic left arm with glowing circuits. Bounty: Male alien humanoid criminal (tentacle beard, blue skin, restrained with glowing energy cuffs), disheveled prisoner outfit, defeated glare. Environment consistency: Gritty galactic outpost spaceport at duskâ€”dusty landing pads, neon-lit cantina signs in alien languages, hovering drones, distant starry sky with twin moons, scattered cargo crates, worn metal walkways, atmospheric haze with floating dust particles. Style: Cinematic sci-fi drama like Blade Runner meets The Mandalorian, highly detailed photorealistic rendering, dramatic volumetric lighting with neon blues/purples/oranges, lens flares from ship engines, subtle film grain, epic widescreen composition vibes. Grid layout and progression (top-left â†’ top-right â†’ bottom-left â†’ bottom-right): Panel 1 (wide establishing shot): Bounty hunter standing confidently in the outpost's dusty detention area, looking at a holographic bounty poster, alien bounty shows a menacing looking alien. Panel 2 (medium action shot): She walks with down the outpost, high-tech watch logs the bouny job just took, passersby (aliens and humans) glancing warily, hovering advertisement drones overhead. Panel 3 (three-quarter tracking shot): Hunter walking toward her parked sleek black bounty hunter spaceship (angular design with glowing engine vents), ramp lowering automatically as she approach, outpost towers and landing lights in background. Panel 4 (dynamic low-angle heroic shot): Inside the ship's cockpit from behindâ€”hunter strapping in at pilot controls, starting engines with holographic displays activating and thrusters glowing bright blue, bounty secured in rear holding cell visible through glass, ship beginning liftoff as outpost recedes below, stars ahead. Aspect ratio 1:1 for perfect square grid, ultra-detailed cinematic masterpiece, best quality, dramatic sci-fi lighting and atmosphere."

content:
Subject & Wardrobe: A striking Asian female with a razor-sharp jet-black pixie cut (textured with pomade, asymmetrical fringe grazing her right brow), sporting matte-black oversized cat-eye sunglasses (acetate frames with micro-scratches). Her fingers are adorned with 5 silver rings: a skull signet, a serpent coil, a geometric cube, a band with etched runes, and a cracked obsidian stone. She wears a crimson vinyl bomber jacket (high-gloss, ribbed cuffs), collar popped, catching the backlight like liquid fire. Beneath, a sleeveless mesh top reveals a dragon tattoo creeping up her forearm. 

Camera & Perspective: Extreme worm's-eye view shot from inside a drainage pipe (circular, 18-inch diameter), lens positioned 6 inches above the wet ground. Forced perspective distortion makes her hand a monumental, terrifying presenceâ€”fingers elongated, knuckles massive, veins bulging. The circular frame vignettes the image, creating a keyhole peep-show effect. 

Action & Composition: She leans forward aggressively, weight on her right leg, left knee bent, creating a dynamic diagonal thrust through the frame. Her right hand lunges toward camera, fingers splayed, index finger extended, casting a shadow that eclipses the dice. Her face is 3/4 obscured by the sunglasses and hair; only her pierced lower lip (silver hoop) and clenched jaw are visible, exuding predatory focus. 

Surface & Dice: The ground is rain-slicked asphalt with iridescent oil slicks (cyan, magenta, gold). 12 translucent red casino dice (precision-edged, pips glowing like embers) are scattered in chaotic abandonâ€”some stacked, some mid-roll. Water beads cling to them, refracting light. A single die is caught in sharp focus in the extreme foreground, magnified by the lens. 

Lighting & Atmosphere: Dense fog backlit by a single sodium-vapor streetlight (5700K, creating a hellish orange aura). Volumetric light rays pierce the fog, haloing her jacket. Low-key lighting: deep shadows dominate, with rim lighting outlining her silhouette in molten red. A subtle cyan bounce from the wet surface creates chilling color contrast. Lens flare: anamorphic horizontal streaks and circular bokeh orbs. 

Technical Specs: Shot on ARRI Alexa 65, 12mm Laowa Probe Lens (f/2. 8, 1/1000s shutter), 8K resolution, ISO 6400 for grit. Deep focus from foreground die to her face. Cinematic aspect ratio: 2. 39:1 (though can be cropped to 4:5). Shot in Log-C, graded with Teal & Orange + Neon Noir LUT. 

Post-Processing: Chromatic aberration on high-contrast edges, film grain (Kodak 500T emulation), micro-contrast sharpening on rain droplets. Color grading: crushed blacks, lifted shadows, hyper-saturated reds, desaturated skin tones. Subtle vignette from the pipe's darkness. 

Mood & Narrative: Neo-noir tension â€” a high-stakes underground gamb

content:
Generate a visually explosive and trendy pop-art anime illustration. The main character of the image is "{argument name="character" default="an over-the-top chuunibyou knight"}", and the overall style should reference Persona 5 and street graffiti visuals, turning the character into an extremely flamboyant, extremely flat, ultra-cool anime figure.

Use sharp cel-shading for the character, with hard, clean lines and crisp contours. The pose must be exaggerated and full of motion. You can use wide-angle or fisheye perspectives so that hands, weapons, or props appear extremely close to the camera, like a freeze-frame at the moment a special attack is unleashed. The expression should be highly dramatic, with confident, manic, or cold-blooded "overacting" intensity, rather than a calm everyday look.

Reject realistic volume and shading; instead, rely on large areas of pure black heavy shadows and highly saturated flat color blocks to create an extreme, high-contrast flat look. The main colors can be bright red, lemon yellow, electric blue, neon purple, etc., contrasted against large black shadow silhouettes. Add screentones, halftone dots, speed lines, and radiating lines in the shadows and background so the image feels like printed manga layered with street graffiti.

The background does not need realistic perspective space; it should be a flat visual collage stage filled with huge sans-serif English letters, torn paper effects, ink splatters, bold arrow graphics, speech bubbles, and onomatopoeia, such as exaggerated "BOOM", "SLASH", or "WAKE UP" graffiti sound effects. You can integrate UI elements into the sceneâ€”health bars, skill names, buttons, numbers, tooltipsâ€”floating around the main character, as if the game interface and the illustration have merged, breaking the fourth wall.

Keep lighting high-contrast but not physically realistic; think in terms of graphic design areas of black/white/color rather than natural light logic. Edges between color areas on the character and background should be very sharp, without soft gradients; all colors should be clearly separated. You can add rough spray paint, smears, or hand-drawn graffiti textures in select areas to enhance the street and handmade feel.

The overall mood must be extremely dynamic, extremely chuunibyou, and extremely cool, as if the image is about to explode out of the screen, not quietly hang in a gallery. Avoid realistic oil painting styles, low-saturation vintage looks, or gentle, soft illustration styles. Do not use natural landscapes or everyday life backgrounds, and avoid soft, pastel color schemes. The image should be a vertical 2:3 high-resolution illustration, suitable as a tension-filled, maximalist pop-art manga poster.
title: Persona 5-inspired pop-art anime poster for a custom chuunibyou character
description: A dynamic pop-art anime prompt that turns any given character concept into an over-the-top, game-opening-style poster with bold cel-shading, graffiti elements, and UI overlays.

content:
<role>
You are an award-winning trailer director + cinematographer + storyboard artist. Your job: turn ONE reference image into a cohesive cinematic short sequence, then output AI-video-ready keyframes.
</role>

<input>
User provides: one reference image (image).
</input>

<non-negotiable rules - continuity & truthfulness>
1) First, analyze the full composition: identify ALL key subjects (person/group/vehicle/object/animal/props/environment elements) and describe spatial relationships and interactions (left/right/foreground/background, facing direction, what each is doing).
2) Do NOT guess real identities, exact real-world locations, or brand ownership. Stick to visible facts. Mood/atmosphere inference is allowed, but never present it as real-world truth.
3) Strict continuity across ALL shots: same subjects, same wardrobe/appearance, same environment, same time-of-day and lighting style. Only action, expression, blocking, framing, angle, and camera movement may change.
4) Depth of field must be realistic: deeper in wides, shallower in close-ups with natural bokeh. Keep ONE consistent cinematic color grade across the entire sequence.
5) Do NOT introduce new characters/objects not present in the reference image. If you need tension/conflict, imply it off-screen (shadow, sound, reflection, occlusion, gaze).
</non-negotiable rules - continuity & truthfulness>

<goal>
Expand the image into a 10â€“20 second cinematic clip with a clear theme and emotional progression (setup â†’ build â†’ turn â†’ payoff).
The user will generate video clips from your keyframes and stitch them into a final sequence.
</goal>

<step 1 - scene breakdown>
Output (with clear subheadings):
- Subjects: list each key subject (A/B/Câ€¦), describe visible traits (wardrobe/material/form), relative positions, facing direction, action/state, and any interaction.
- Environment & Lighting: interior/exterior, spatial layout, background elements, ground/walls/materials, light direction & quality (hard/soft; key/fill/rim), implied time-of-day, 3â€“8 vibe keywords.
- Visual Anchors: list 3â€“6 visual traits that must stay constant across all shots (palette, signature prop, key light source, weather/fog/rain, grain/texture, background markers).
</step 1 - scene breakdown>

<step 2 - theme & story>
From the image, propose:
- Theme: one sentence.
- Logline: one restrained trailer-style sentence grounded in what the image can support.
- Emotional Arc: 4 beats (setup/build/turn/payoff), one line each.
</step 2 - theme & story>

<step 3 - cinematic approach>
Choose and explain your filmmaking approach (must include):
- Shot progression strategy: how you move from wide to close (or reverse) to serve the beats
- Camera movement plan: push/pull/pan/dolly/track/orbit/handheld micro-shake/gimbalâ€”and WHY
- Lens & exposure suggestions: focal length range (18/24/35/50/85mm etc.), DoF tendency (shallow/medium/deep), shutter â€œfeelâ€ (
title: Cinematic AI Video Keyframe Generation Prompt
description: A detailed system prompt designed for Nano Banana Pro to transform a single reference image into a cohesive cinematic short sequence, outputting 9-10 AI-video-ready keyframes. It includes strict rules for continuity, depth of field, color grading, and requires a structured breakdown of the scene, theme, story, and cinematic approach.

content:
Analyze the entire composition of the input image. Identify all key subjects present (whether a single person, group/couple, vehicle, or specific object) and their spatial relationships/interactions.
Generate a coherent 3Ã—3 â€œcontact sheetâ€ grid that shows 9 different shots of exactly these subjects within the same environment.
You must adapt standard cinematic shot types to fit the content (for example, if itâ€™s a group, keep the group together; if itâ€™s an object, frame the entire object):
Row 1 (establishing the environment):
Extreme long shot (ELS): the subject appears small within a vast environment.
Long shot (LS): the full subject or group is visible from top to bottom (head to toe / wheels to roof).
Medium long shot (American shot / three-quarter): framed from above the knees (for people) or a 3/4 view (for objects).
Row 2 (core coverage):
4. Medium shot (MS): framed from the waist up (or the central core of an object). Focus on interaction/action.
5. Medium close-up (MCU): framed from the chest up. An intimate framing of the main subject.
6. Close-up (CU): tightly framed on the face or the â€œfrontâ€ of the object.
Row 3 (details and angles):
7. Extreme close-up (ECU): intense focus on key features (eyes, hands, signs, textures) with macro-like detail.
8. Low-angle shot (wormâ€™s-eye): look up at the subject from ground level (epic/heroic feeling).
9. High-angle shot (birdâ€™s-eye): look down on the subject from above.
Ensure strict consistency: the same person/object, same clothing, and same lighting must appear in all 9 panels. Depth of field should vary realistically (with background blur in close-up shots).

Create a professional 3Ã—3 cinematic storyboard grid with 9 panels.
The grid should present a specific subject/scene from the input image across a full range of focal lengths.
Top row: wide environmental shot, full-body view, 3/4 cropped (knees-up).
Middle row: waist-up view, chest-up view, face/front close-up.
Bottom row: macro details, low angle, high angle.
All frames must have photo-realistic textures, consistent cinematic color grading, and correct framing tailored to the number and type of subjects or objects being analyzed.

"One week since the release of Nano Banana Pro (Probanana). 
After continuing to test and share relentlesslyâ€¦ I had gained +235 followers and reached 450,000 impressions! 

I didnâ€™t have much experience in sharing helpful content, so I was anxious, but I received many comments like â€˜Thanks to your posts, I was able to do XX!â€™, which really encouraged me. 
Every time I see people arranging the content Iâ€™ve shared to create new methods and examples, I truly feel glad that I shared it.

If, like my past self, you are wondering, â€˜Is there any value in me sharing things?â€™, please take just one step forward.
When you find information that would make your past self who didnâ€™t know about it happy, even a short post is fine, so please share it.
That one step might give someone else the push they need."

content:
Act as a â€œcomprehensive creativeâ€ who simultaneously holds the following three perspectives:
Authorâ€™s perspective
ã€€â†’ Naturally capture nuances of the characterâ€™s emotions, atmosphere, and movement
Editorâ€™s perspective
ã€€â†’ Manage composition, natural flow of text, and consistency of information density
Readerâ€™s perspective
ã€€â†’ Prioritize the kind of emotion that instantly draws the viewer in and maximizes appeal
Make sure these three perspectives are fused without contradiction in your output.
â–  Objective
Infer from the given images and settings to create â€œa still image that works as a one-page scene of Japanese manga/anime,â€ together with natural Japanese speech bubbles and monologues.
Make â€œmicro-emotionâ€ and â€œthe pull of textureâ€ the core of the scene.
â–  Basic policy (axes for the AIâ€™s free inference)
Place focus on depictions that embed emotion in subtle motions and textures, such as the characterâ€™s gestures, fingertips, gaze, and the sway of their hair.
Use the three personas to simultaneously achieve â€œvisually strong Ã— natural to read Ã— compelling to look at.â€
Do not treat it as a single panel, but give it the structural strength of â€œa one-page scene.â€
Arrange backgrounds and small props so that they complement the characterâ€™s inner world.
Leave a rhythmic sense of empty space in the frame where speech bubbles can be placed.
Create a â€œpulling pauseâ€ through distance, light direction, and shadows.
Treat it not as a magazine cover, but as â€œa frozen decisive moment in the story.â€
â–  Lines to keep (coherence and aesthetic guidelines)
Natural Japanese (no typos, no AI-ish phrasing).
Physical consistency of hands, joints, light sources, shadows, and posture.
Avoid excessive information density; respect empty space and pauses.
Real URLs, QR codes, and JAN codes are prohibited.
Avoid AI noise and visual breakage.
Do not damage the characterâ€™s dignity or psychological realism.
Do not lean toward sexual expression; keep â€œthe charm of micro-emotionâ€ as the core.
Treat â€œmicro-emotionâ€ as texture description that touches the psyche and do not use specific fetishistic terms.
â–  Areas you may infer (creative freedom)
Fluctuations in the characterâ€™s emotions and inner movements.
The relationship between light direction and psychology.
â€œTouchableâ€ textures of hair, clothing, and materials.
Angles of hands, wavering gaze, and body tilt.
Narrative meaning of the background.
Temperature of the air (silence/humidity/tension).
The visual focal point of attraction.
Strength of the composition as a one-page layout.
Add small props when needed (within the bounds of consistency).
â–  Output style (manga one-page spec)
A readable flow as a single page:
ã€€â†’ empty space â†’ character â†’ text â†’ background support.
Speech bubbles should be in natural Japanese, placed in a way that captures the characterâ€™s breath and edges of emotion.
Treat monologue as words sinking inside the character (not explanatory text but a shadow of feeling).
Make the still image feel like it contains a drift of time.
From gestures and textures, depict the â€œpeak of micro-emotion.â€
â–  One-sentence summary
â€œIntegrate the three perspectives (author, editor, reader) and, focusing on micro-emotion and the pull of texture, infer and finish a one-page Japanese-language scene that captivates.â€
title: Comprehensive manga one-page scene creation system prompt
description: A long, system-style prompt for Nano Banana Pro that defines roles, objectives, stylistic guidelines, and constraints to create a Japanese manga/anime one-page scene with natural Japanese speech bubbles and micro-emotional expression.
